“我们正处于一个危险的时刻，”北莱茵-威斯特法伦州雇主协会的负责人 Arndt Kirchhoff 担心道，他是经营汽车零部件制造商 Kirchhoff 的三兄弟之一。德国最近陷入技术性衰退。许多公司在国外而不是在国内投资。疫情限制解除后，中国消费者的进口量低于德国制造商的预期。而乌克兰对俄罗斯侵略者的反攻正在给德国的后院注入不确定性。

5 月，智库 Ifo Institute 的商业信心指数七个月来首次下降（见图表）。 6 月 5 日，机械制造商的主要游说团体vDMA宣布，上个月工程公司的订单同比下降 20%，制造商的悲观情绪变得更加阴沉。 GDP小幅收缩（德国产出第一季度下降了 0.3%）可能会对机械制造商的订单产生重大影响。然而，订单下降也“反映了近期经济情绪的恶化”， vDMA的奥拉夫·沃特曼 (Olaf Wortmann) 感叹道。由社会民主党、绿党和自由民主党组成的执政联盟承诺在商业和经济事务上实现新的“德国速度”，但在幻想破灭的德国老板看来，这似乎越来越像爬行。

根据最近对工业企业的调查，雇主最紧迫的担忧是原材料和能源的价格（两者都居高不下）；熟练劳动力的可用性（供不应求）；工资上涨（进一步推高成本）。甚至不要让老板开始处理繁文缛节。官僚审批仍然需要很长时间。一项挑剔的新法律要求在德国拥有 3,000 多名员工的公司监督其在世界各地的供应商是否符合人权和环境标准。经济部长罗伯特·哈贝克 (Robert Habeck) 于 6 月 6 日在北莱茵-威斯特法伦州巴特贝勒堡 (Bad Berleburg) 落成的风电场耗时十年建成。 “我们必须加快审批流程，”哈贝克先生在就职典礼上承认。他坚称，到 2030 年，德国将设法将其风力发电能力翻一番。但他自己承认，这需要将风电场的发展速度提高两倍。

德国公司越来越不愿意努力进行投资和扩张。根据经济研究机构ZEW Mannheim 的数据，在 21 个工业化国家中，他们的国家在家族企业开展业务的地点中排名第 18 位（美国、加拿大和瑞典位居前三）。 “过去 20 年来，我们一直走在错误的道路上，”领先的胶带制造商 Coroplast 的首席执行官 Natalie Mekelburger 感叹道。 Mekelburger 女士说，州政府对企业的干预“间接地摧毁了创业力量”，她特别指责绿党采用“计划经济方法”。

近三分之一的德国中型中小企业正在考虑将生产和工作岗位转移到国外；六分之一的人已经在这样做了。 BioNTech 是一家帮助开发 covid-19 疫苗的先驱生物技术公司，正在英国建立其癌症研究中心。加热设备制造商 Viessmann 正在将其核心热泵业务出售给美国开利公司。 “我们正面临逐渐去工业化的危险，”电锯领先制造商斯蒂尔的监事会主席尼古拉斯·斯蒂尔警告说。

斯蒂尔先生的公司不打算将生产转移到其他地方。但他希望 BioNTech 和 Viessmann 的决定能为政府敲响警钟。他说，如果德国像过去一样对商业友好，这两种举措都不会发生。 ■

; Thu, 08 Jun 2023 13:48:58 GMT /内容/9kq2np29bgleu1ptk2fmebg9hin9sl6j https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/08/german-bosses-are-depressed Why employee loyalty can be overrated

求职面试是一个实时了解忠诚度转变的机会。候选人通常会在面试开始时将未来的雇主称为“您”（“您希望从这个职位的人身上看到什么？”）。但有时代词会发生变化（“我们应该更多地考虑我们的线下营销方法。抱歉，我的意思是‘你’应该是”）。那个“我们”是一个微小的、时间旅行的一瞥，一个人把自己想象成一家新公司的员工，一个新的身份被伪造，忠诚被转移。

在大多数情况下，忠诚被视为一种美德：在朋友、家人和球迷之间。然而，员工忠诚度更为复杂。它更具交易性。朋友们不会因为成本原因互相评价或解雇对方。它的互惠性较低。工人可以对公司产生依恋感，而公司则完全没有感觉。 （这就是为什么人们往往对团队成员和个人老板比对他们的组织更忠诚。）太多会带来高成本。

工资上涨和职业生涯是建立在人们换工作的基础上的。根据追踪美国工资增长的亚特兰大联邦储备银行的数据，4 月份跳槽者的工资比去年同期高出 7.6%；工作贴纸的报酬仅高出 5.6%。其他人的一点滥交可以帮助那些选择留在原地的人。澳大利亚财政部官员内森·多伊彻 (Nathan Deutscher) 发表的一篇论文发现，澳大利亚当地劳动力市场较高的跳槽率与较快的工资增长有关，无论是跳槽的工人还是没有跳槽的工人。忠诚是好的；议价能力也是如此。

过多的忠诚度会以其他方式伤害员工。今年早些时候，杜克大学的马修·斯坦利 (Matthew Stanley) 和他的合著者发表了一项研究，测试了老板对忠诚员工的看法。研究人员询问经理们，他们是否愿意让一位名叫约翰的虚构员工无偿加班。如果约翰被形容为忠诚，那么老板们更乐意将更多工作交给他。反之亦然：工作更多却没有回报的员工更有可能被管理者描述为忠诚的。请记住，狗以忠诚着称，但不是因为他们的大脑。

雇主往往对产生忠诚度的因素一清二楚。保留奖金是承认最优秀的员工可能需要一点推动才能留下来。真正的忠诚往往会得到无意义的回报：为 25 年的服务提供一周的额外假期？ Netflix 鼓励其员工与招聘人员交谈，以便他们了解自己在公开市场上的价值，并以还价作为回应（这种方法在你准备支付高价时更有意义，而如果你在非营利部门）。

尽管如此，公司还是会执着于忠诚的理念。 1950 年代离开肖克利半导体实验室创立仙童半导体的这群员工被称为“八大卖国”。一些这种态度仍然盛行。但除非你是黑手党成员或牧师，否则加入竞争对手既不是背叛也不是异端。事实上，回旋镖雇员——离开雇主然后又回来的人——可以提供已知数量和新技能的宝贵结合。

如果员工忠诚度过高，社会就会受到影响。芝加哥大学的詹姆斯·邓根 (James Dungan) 及其合著者于 2019 年发表的一篇关于举报的论文发现，如果员工关心的是组织外部人员的公平待遇，他们就更有可能举报不当行为，而这样做的可能性较小如果他们更受忠诚的激励。其他研究表明，竞争环境会鼓励一个群体的忠诚成员为了打败另一个群体而作弊。

员工忠诚度可能很高。公司需要对自己忠诚的员工，他们愿意付出更多的努力，而不是在接到通知后立即加入竞争对手的行列。工人们希望相信并属于一家公司，相信它可以保证他们在地球上度过有限的大部分时间。就工作满意度和绩效而言，如果员工留在原地是因为他们觉得对他们的组织有投资，而不是因为他们没有得到更好的工作机会，这对周围更好。但工作场所的忠诚度是一种自利决定，而不是道德决定。它应该取决于受到良好的对待，而不是一种变得更难改掉的习惯。留在原地是因为你喜欢它，而不是因为离开是不道德的。 ■

; Thu, 08 Jun 2023 13:48:58 GMT /内容/pod7ikhd18bpiov43boa8ie0t6parucc https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/08/why-employee-loyalty-can-be-overrated What TIM’s mega-spin-off reveals about Europe’s telecoms industry

即使按照意大利混乱的标准，该国最大的电信服务提供商TIM Group 也是一只奇怪的野兽。在过去的七年里，它换了五位首席执行官。它积累了超过 250 亿欧元（合 270 亿美元）的净债务，成为欧洲大型电信公司中负债最多的。而现在，为了降低负载，它想做同行都没有做过的事情，即出售其主要资产：固定网络。当TIM最新的新老板 Pietro Labriola 解释分拆时，他并没有拐弯抹角。随着利率上升，债务负担变得沉重。所有三大评级机构现在都将TIM的债务评为低于投资级别。出售预计价值超过 200 亿欧元的固定网络是“重获工业选择权的最明确方式”。报价原定于 6 月 9 日送达。

TIM是一个极端的例子。然而，它的举动在很大程度上揭示了欧洲高度分散的电信行业的发展方向。美国和中国的运营商屈指可数；欧洲有 100 多家。虽然有些是大公司的本地子公司，但它们仍在拼凑的国家市场中竞争。如果更多的欧洲运营商效仿TIM的做法，将他们的固定网络从其他资产中分离出来（这看起来很有可能），那么具有讽刺意味的是，这种“分层”可能会成为整合的第一步。

欧洲电信的近期历史是宏伟的抱负之一。大多数都失败了。在过去的二十年里，该行业的许多公司已成为大型综合运营商。他们为世界各地的消费者和企业提供各种服务。他们的总年收入总计超过 2650 亿欧元。有些人不仅尝试成为网络运营商，还涉足科技和媒体领域，结果却发现自己在创新方面落后于美国的数字巨头和初创公司。

在财务上，这个故事也好不到哪儿去。在 2000 年代初，运营商为3G无线电频谱支付了太多费用；包括 Orange（原法国电信）和德国电信在内的一些公司几乎破产了。 New Street Research 的 James Ratzer 解释说，为了挽救他们，监管机构允许他们在几年内赚取巨额利润，只是为了通过促进竞争的措施重新控制他们，例如向新进入者发放许可和限制欧洲漫游费用，股票分析公司 New Street Research 的 James Ratzer精品店。与此同时，预计电信公司将加大对固定和移动网络的投资。他们的老板抱怨必须适应从谷歌到 Netflix 等美国数字巨头向消费者提供的海量数据。他们说，大型科技公司产生了所有互联网流量的一半以上，但对建设基础设施毫无贡献。 （欧盟委员会已经展开磋商，预计很快就会有结果。）

根据 New Street 的数据，由于这一切，该行业的已动用资本回报率已从平均 18% 的健康水平降至微不足道的 8%。尽管他们设法将大量光纤电缆一直连接到人们的家中，包括连接到从瑞典到西班牙等地的偏远村庄，但他们的低回报可能使他们无法像美国同行那样迅速推出5G移动网络或中国。最近竞争变得不那么激烈，允许运营商提高价格。即便如此，投资者仍保持谨慎。电信股落后于欧洲几乎所有其他行业。

延迟可能是将行业从无利可图的荒野中拯救出来的最佳机会。据咨询公司麦肯锡计算，2014 年 O2 Czech Republic 在被私募股权基金收购后将自己拆分为网络和服务公司，两部分的总价值几乎翻了一番。 TIM是一家大得多的公司，因此也是一个更大的测试案例。欧洲电信大佬们因此对TIM的拆解看得很仔细。一旦 Labriola 先生卖掉了固定网络，他打算让他的剩余公司专注于三项业务，每项业务都必须有自己的财务状况：其在意大利的消费品牌；为企业客户提供云计算服务；以及一家大型外国子公司TIM Brazil。如果他成功了，他的对手将很想效仿他。

许多公司，例如 Orange，已经在内部将自己拆分成独立的业务部门，提供从云计算到网络访问的不同服务。一些公司已经剥离了他们的无线电塔。随着网络越来越受软件控制，分离变得更加容易。投资者可以在电信市场中选择适合他们风险偏好的那一块。有些人可能喜欢固定网络的可预测经济学：美国私募股权巨头KKR愿意为TIM支付至少 200 亿欧元（第二个竞标者是国有银行 Cassa Depositi e Prestiti，它拥有10% 的TIM ，并给予意大利政府更多的控制权）。其他人可能更喜欢更具活力的移动业务。

连接问题

正如 Labriola 先生指出的那样，一旦TIM的固定网络被剥离，监管机构就更有可能让他将其移动业务与另一家运营商的业务相结合。事实上，该行业已经加倍努力说服委员会和国家竞争主管部门的反垄断机构让更多的公司合并。合并的希望或许可以解释为什么帕特里克·德拉希 (Patrick Drahi) 和泽维尔·尼尔 (Xavier Niel) 这两位欧洲电信业的法国顽童分别增持了两家陷入困境的英国运营商英国电信(BT ) 和沃达丰 (Vodafone) 的股份。 Orange 和 MásMóvil 在西班牙拟议的移动婚姻将是一个早期测试，预计将在今年晚些时候做出决定。

一些欧洲电信业老板抱怨市场分散会抑制资本支出是自私自利的。碎片化并没有阻止他们建设强大的光纤网络，这可能比移动网络更昂贵。欧洲可能在 5 g上落后于美国，但欧洲大陆的光纤覆盖范围现在比大西洋彼岸要好得多。欧洲电信公司的许多问题都源于他们想做的太多。如果他们认识到这一点和拖延者，布鲁塞尔应该让他们放松一些。 ■

; Thu, 08 Jun 2023 13:48:58 GMT /内容/gg5ie3id25ejrjq73r3qastcp78pdg9m https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/08/what-tims-mega-spin-off-reveals-about-europes-telecoms-industry PwC has disgraced itself down under

澳大利亚总理A NTHONY ALBANESE称其“完全不能接受”。他的财务主管吉姆·查默斯 (Jim Chalmers) “怒不可遏”。他们愤怒的对象是P w C 。这家专业服务巨头因被指控在帮助政府设计新系统使外国跨国公司缴纳更多税款后，利用其内部知识帮助全球客户规避这些相同措施而陷入困境。

丑闻集中在 Peter-John Collins 身上，他是普华永道前合伙人，他在 2013 年至 2015 年期间就税收规则向政府提供咨询，然后将工作细节泄露给澳大利亚和国外至少 53 名合伙人。澳大利亚税务局怀疑跨国公司的适应速度，于 2018 年向澳大利亚联邦警察局提出了此事，并于 2020 年向认证机构税务从业者委员会 ( TPB ) 提出了这个问题。

今年 1 月，据透露， TPB已于去年年底禁止 Collins 先生因该事件从事税务工作两年。从那时起，这件事就升级为普华永道名誉扫地的噩梦。 5 月 8 日，其澳大利亚老板卸任。 5 月 31 日，澳大利亚中央银行表示，在重建信任之前，它将把该公司排除在未来的合同之外。 6 月 2 日，澳大利亚最大的养老基金 AustralianSuper 采取了类似的措施；第二大澳大利亚退休信托基金也在 6 月 6 日效仿。澳大利亚联邦政府的许多部门，普华永道在该国最大的客户，将审查他们的关系。

普华永道的澳大利亚业务已就此事件道歉，称这是“不可接受的”。它已经启动了自己的调查，并正在“围栏”其与联邦政府的业务，以尽量减少潜在的利益冲突。这可能不足以平息愤怒。 6 月 7 日，澳大利亚参议院开始就政府与咨询业的关系展开听证会。其调查结果将于 9 月公布。

这一事件也再次引发了关于普华永道及其竞争对手德勤、安永和毕马威所采用的“多学科”模式的尴尬问题，这些模式将审计、管理咨询和税务咨询集中在一个屋檐下。近年来，审计而非税收一直是丑闻的焦点。今年早些时候，安永在德国因未能发现 Wirecard 的虚假账簿而受到谴责，Wirecard 是德国金融科技的宠儿，于 2020 年倒闭。德勤和毕马威在英国都因审计失误而陷入困境。

这些损害声誉的混乱局面为那些主张将审计与公司其他业务分开的人提供了支持，比如安永的全球老板。这将使顾问能够逃避阻止他们就其他事项为审计客户提供服务的独立性规则。这一最新事件表明，占“四大”总收入约五分之一的税务业务也可能是一项负债，正如普华永道的审计和咨询业务所发现的那样。

这不是税收第一次引起恶臭。 2005 年，毕马威 (KPMG)因其涉嫌向客户宣传非法避税行为而在美国险些逃脱刑事起诉，而是以 4.56 亿美元的巨额罚款和解。定罪将禁止该公司审计上市公司，这可能是致命的。普华永道在澳大利亚的噩梦再次打击了四大的多学科模式。 ■

; Thu, 08 Jun 2023 13:48:57 GMT /内容/6fk4p69d9hq36l7c3lor5e39rtmro29t https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/08/pwc-has-disgraced-itself-down-under Why Sequoia Capital is sawing off its Chinese branch

N EIL SHEN在中国私募股权行业有着神一样的地位。红杉中国的牵头交易撮合者在中国一些最成功的科技公司，如超级外卖应用美团和电子商务巨头拼多多，在早期就下了大笔赌注。现在，沉先生的投资公司正计划单干，放弃红杉的名字，并最终切断与其硅谷母公司的所有联系。

6 月 6 日，拥有 51 年历史的风险投资行业中坚力量红杉资本宣布将拆分为独立的美国、中国和印度业务。一段时间以来，红杉中国以高度自主的方式运作，沉先生说了算。由 Shailendra Singh 领导的红杉资本的印度和东南亚业务也是如此。到 2024 年 3 月，这些实体将不再像他们多年来所做的那样分享投资者或回报。中国分支将被称为红杉，红木的普通话。红杉资本表示，拆分是“本地优先”方法的一部分，该方法专为“经营分散的全球投资业务变得越来越复杂”的世界而设计。

沉先生的许多投资确实是为了一个全球化、互联的世界。他是滴滴出行的投资者，滴滴出行是一家中国网约车公司，2021 年该公司在纽约上市受到中国政府的阻挠。他希望通过投资 LinkedIn 的中国分公司，让美国社交媒体在他的祖国发挥作用。专业人士的平台——在审查制度和繁重的规则迫使 LinkedIn 几乎完全放弃这个国家之前。

与此同时，在美国，抨击中国几乎是民主党和共和党唯一可以达成共识的地方，红杉资本和其他投资者面临越来越大的退出中国的政治压力。蒙大拿州刚刚禁止了 TikTok，这是一款短视频应用程序，红杉资本和红杉中国均持有其中国母公司字节跳动的股份。大疆是红杉中国部分持有的中国大型无人机制造商，被列入美国投资黑名单。

中国的投资者和银行家将红杉资本的决定视为中国正在失去与世界其他地区的重要商业联系的迹象。外商的环境确实变黑了。中国当局对几家西方咨询公司的突击搜查令跨国公司紧张不安。经济的黯淡前景也是如此，在大流行时期的严格封锁后重新开放对经济的提振低于预期。 5 月份进出口双双下滑超过预期。政府针对中国数字巨头的为期两年的运动虽然现在应该已经结束，但留下了深深的伤痕。共产党在有前途的科技公司中持有越来越多的股份。

令人担忧的地缘政治和严厉的国内政治正在对中国私人资产的投资造成影响。根据咨询公司贝恩的数据，专注于此类赌注的基金去年在全球仅筹集了 250 亿美元，比前一年下降了 77%（见图表）。大中华区相对于亚洲其他地区的筹资份额已降至 15 年来的最低点。去年，中国私募股权的交易价值下跌了一半以上，跌幅超过该地区其他任何地方。红杉不太可能是最后一个退出的。 ■

; Thu, 08 Jun 2023 10:19:09 GMT /内容/jp62beg7ul29k97lc1s4jhcn6qd3pnkc https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/08/why-sequoia-capital-is-sawing-off-its-chinese-branch The PGA agrees to team up with its golfing arch-enemy

许多商业交易都是在高尔夫球场上完成的。就在 6 月 6 日，男子高尔夫最大的组织机构美国PGA巡回赛和欧洲DP世界巡回赛表示，他们已同意与沙特阿拉伯的新贵LIV Golf 合并。据报道，此次合并将使LIV的支持者向合并后的实体投资约 30 亿美元，结束了这场代价高昂的分裂，并使沙特人成为体育界最尊贵的俱乐部之一。

LIV Golf 于去年 6 月开球，由沙特阿拉伯 6500 亿美元的主权财富基金提供资金。它为通常上流社会的游戏带来了为电视制作的狂欢。较短的锦标赛以名为 Crushers 的球队为特色。礼貌的掌声让位于欢呼声。明星球员获得了一大笔钱来参加比赛，尽管有人担心沙特人是“可怕的混蛋”，用收了钱的菲尔·米克尔森的话来说。留住人才，老游挥舞着胡萝卜和九号铁杆。他们增加了奖金（如果没有达到沙特的水平），禁止叛逃者加入LIV ，并强调沙特阿拉伯的人权记录。 PGA和LIV已经起诉和反诉对方干涉对方的业务。

这笔交易扼杀了这些诉讼（以及沙特官员不得不在美国法庭出庭的前景）。报名参加LIV的球员将受到欢迎回到PGA 。那些出于道德原因或避免惹恼他们的赞助商而避开沙特人的人可能会感到很难受。

既定的旅行团面临虚伪的指责。但这笔交易保护他们免受与LIV 的竞争。与此同时，沙特阿拉伯又在其内阁中增加了另一个体育奖杯，其中已经拥有像克里斯蒂亚诺罗纳尔多这样的足球明星（一月份被诱惑参加其国内联赛）和一年一度的一级方程式大奖赛。体育使其经济多样化，让焦躁不安的年轻沙特人保持娱乐，并分散外国人对政权不愉快的注意力。掌管主权基金的王子们可能也觉得它比碳氢化合物更受欢迎。

高尔夫球迷们将会看到更多的大明星，可能还会看到更多以团队为基础的活泼比赛。 PGA的老板杰伊·莫纳汉 (Jay Monahan) 称赞这次合作是“变革性的”。其他运动可能想知道石油资金接下来会流向哪里。 ■

; Wed, 07 Jun 2023 20:41:31 GMT /内容/05gqr3h02a259k7uu7qd3993j​​7g3efvm https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/07/the-pga-agrees-to-team-up-with-its-golfing-arch-enemy Generative AI could radically alter the practice of law

律师是一群保守的人，适合奖励准备充分、睿智和尊重先例的职业。纽约律师事务所 Levidow, Levidow & Oberman 的人身伤害律师史蒂文·施瓦茨 (Steven Schwartz) 上个月使用 Chat GPT帮助他准备一份法庭文件，这无疑让很多人大笑不已。他过于依赖人工智能 ( AI ) 聊天机器人。它创建了一个充满虚构案例、裁决和引述的动议，在机器人向他保证“我提供的案例是真实的，并且可以在信誉良好的法律数据库中找到”（它们不是，也不能）后，Schwartz 先生立即提交了该动议.吸取教训后，对技术持怀疑态度的律师可能会得出结论：旧方法是最好的。

那是错误的教训。将 Schwartz 先生充满错误的简报归咎于人工智能，这与将打字简报中的错误归咎于印刷机毫无意义。在这两种情况下，错误都在于未能在提交动议之前检查动议的律师，而不是帮助产生动议的工具。因为这就是人工智能：既不是时尚也不是世界末日，而是一种处于起步阶段的工具——一种可以从根本上改变律师工作方式和律师事务所赚钱方式的工具。法律行业并不是唯一可以这样说的领域。但很少有人能将具有如此高风险的用例结合得如此清楚。做对的公司将获得回报。落后者冒着重蹈排字者覆辙的风险。

根据高盛银行最近的一份报告，44% 的法律任务可以由AI执行，比除文书和行政支持外的任何被调查职业都要多。律师花费大量时间仔细审查繁琐的文件——AI已经证明它可以很好地处理这类事情。律师将人工智能用于各种任务，包括尽职调查、研究和数据分析。这些应用程序在很大程度上依赖于“提取式”人工智能，顾名思义，它从文本中提取信息，回答有关其内容的特定问题。

“生成式”人工智能诸如 Chat GPT之类的功能要强大得多。该权力的一部分可用于改进法律研究和文件审查。正如名为 CoCounsel 的生成式人工智能“法律助理”的创建者 Pablo Arredondo 所解释的那样，使用它“消除了关键字的专制……它可以告诉我们‘我们逆转Jenkins ’ [一个虚构的法律案件] 和‘我们遗憾地委托Jenkins到历史的垃圾箱”也是一回事。 Allen & Overy 是一家位于伦敦的大型公司，已将名为 Harvey 的法律人工智能工具集成到其实践中，将其用于合同分析、尽职调查和诉讼准备。

并非所有律师都相信。最近的一项调查发现，82% 的人认为生成式人工智能可以用于法律工作，但只有 51% 的人认为应该这样做。许多人担心会出现“幻觉”（因为人工智能研究人员指的是聊天机器人倾向于泰然自若地撒谎，就像在施瓦茨先生的案例中一样）以及无意中将受律师-委托人特权保护的信息输入算法。然而，如果这些挑战能够得到解决——而且他们可以，在循环中有更好的技术和细心的人——那么持怀疑态度的 49% 的人的疑虑可能会消失。例如，在 Schwartz 先生惨败的消息传出后，得克萨斯州的一名联邦法官告诉在他面前出庭的律师提交一份证明，证明他们要么根本没有使用生成式 AI，要么如果使用了，他们会检查最终结果。一旦 Westlaw 和 LexisNexis 的更大、更容易搜索的数据库只需点击一下鼠标，律师坚持在图书馆进行法律研究就没有什么意义了，当大量公司采用生成人工智能时，将会有更多公司效仿。

人工智能有可能在三大方面改变法律行业。首先，它会削弱大公司的人力优势。在大型、复杂的诉讼中，这些公司要求数十名同事阅读数百万页的文件，以寻找高级律师问题和预感的答案。现在，单个律师或小公司将能够将这些文件上传到诉讼准备AI中并开始查询它们。正如哈佛法学院的劳伦斯·莱西格 (Lawrence Lessig) 所指出的那样，“你可以成为一家更小、更精简的专业公司，并有能力处理这类案件。”

计费权力

其次，人工智能可以改变公司赚钱的方式。英国首席大法官的技术顾问理查德·萨斯金德 (Richard Susskind) 认为，公司通过“拥有大批年轻律师而获利，他们支付给他们的费用低于向客户收取的费用”。如果人工智能可以在几秒钟内完成这些军队的工作，公司将需要改变他们的计费方式。有些人可能会转向根据提供的服务收取固定费用，而不是根据提供服务所花费的时间。 Silicon Valley Law Group 的 Stephen Wu 推测，公司可能会收取“技术费”，这样“客户就不会期望白白获得生成人工智能”。

第三，人工智能可以改变现有律师的数量和工作地点。 Eventually, Mr Lessig argues, it is hard to see how AI “doesn't dramatically reduce the number of lawyers the world needs”. If AI can do in 20 seconds a task that would have taken a dozen associates 50 hours each, then why would big firms continue hiring dozens of associates? A veteran partner at a prestigious corporate-law firm in New York expects the ratio of associates to partners to decline from today's average of perhaps seven to one at the top firms to closer to parity. If associates aren't worried about their jobs, he says, “they should be”.

That may not happen for a while, however. Moreover, AI could make legal services cheaper and thus more widely available, particularly for small and medium-sized businesses that currently often struggle to afford them. Ambitious law-school graduates may find that AI provides an easier path to starting a solo practice. If so, then AI could actually lead to an increase in the overall number of lawyers, as well as changing the sort of tasks they perform—just as the ATM led to an increase in the number of human bank employees rather than their replacement.

Ultimately this will be good news for clients. “People who go to lawyers don't want lawyers: they want resolutions to their problems or the avoidance of problems altogether,” explains Mr Susskind. If AI can provide those outcomes then people will use AI . Many people already use software to do their taxes rather than rely on professionals; “Very few of them are complaining about the lack of social interaction with their tax advisers.” ■

; Tue, 06 Jun 2023 20:14:03 GMT /content/lic6r9vqtrrgasocaesk5v1sstb1rimd https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/06/generative-ai-could-radically-alter-the-practice-of-law Apple’s Vision Pro is a technical marvel. Will anyone buy it?

“C ERTAIN PRODUCTS …shift the way we look at technology,” said Tim Cook, Apple's boss, as he unveiled the tech giant's latest gadget on June 5th. The Vision Pro, a headset for virtual and augmented reality ( VR and AR in the lingo), whose development has been rumoured for years, will be available early next year. With more than 5,000 patents, Apple dubbed the sleek glass goggles “the most ambitious product we've ever created”.

It may also turn out to be one of their lowest-selling. The company had reportedly hoped to shift some 3m units in the first year. But expectations have been scaled back; some analysts now expect Apple to ship fewer than 200,000 units in 12 months, an order of magnitude less than any other big product launch. The Vision Pro's first iteration may be a commercial flop. Yet it is also the first step on the way to something that Apple hopes will be much bigger.

The tech, which Apple has yet to let the public get its hands on, looks impressive. Unlike other headsets, which tend to require hand-held controllers, the Vision Pro is controlled by hand gestures, voice commands and eye movements. It tracks eyes like a mouse, and recognises irises in lieu of a password. It is a “pass-through” device, which uses front-mounted cameras to show the user a video view of the world around them. And to make them appear more normal to others, it projects a video image of their eyes onto the front of the glass. (An Apple ad shows a man making his children breakfast while wearing it, something you would struggle to do with most headsets.)

The chief reason for the projected low sales is the price. At $3,499, the device is more than three times as expensive as Meta's rival VR and AR headset, the Quest Pro, and more than ten times as expensive as the Quest 2, the social-media firm's widely used VR device. Even at this price, Apple's gadget has had to make some technical compromises. It has a clunky external battery, connected to the headset by a cable, which lasts only two hours. And though Apple's designers have done their best to make it as sleek as possible, it is still an awkward thing to strap to your face.

Such challenges have forced many competitors to rethink their involvement in virtual and augmented realities. Meta seems to be scaling back its enthusiasm, following investors' complaints about its spending and, reportedly, weak sales of the Quest Pro despite a steep price cut since its launch in October. Microsoft, a software giant, has put on hold the idea of making another HoloLens, an AR device that is mainly used by corporate clients. Snap, another social-media firm, seems in no hurry to bring out a new version of its AR Spectacles. Tencent, a Chinese digital titan, abandoned its VR hardware plans in February.

It isn't unusual for new products to take time to take off. Apple's past hits mostly took several years before they really caught on (see chart 1). Sales of the Apple Watch were low until people decided that its key use was for monitoring their health. The iPhone didn't really take off until its fourth generation, in 2010, by which time the App Store was populated with thousands of apps that made people realise what the phone could do. Discovering more use cases for the iPhone also helped to justify its price. The device was considered ludicrously expensive when it launched at up to $599; these days a top model costs $1,599, a price people are willing to pay because it can do so much. Perhaps Apple can normalise paying thousands of dollars for a pair of glasses in the same way.

Still, the Vision Pro is launching at a particularly early stage. Rather than a true consumer product, it is more like an “expensive developer kit”, says one maker of AR components. Releasing a developer-oriented product at this stage is a “new frontier” for Apple, says George Jijiashvili of Omdia, a firm of analysts.

There are two reasons for it wanting to get the product out early. One is competitive pressure, chiefly from Meta, which despite retrenching a little has been on a hiring and acquiring spree in its aim to make the “metaverse” into reality. As well as hoovering up talent, Meta has been recruiting users. Already about 10% of Americans use a VR headset at least once a month, according to Insider Intelligence, a data firm. Most of those sets are made by Meta, which has been flogging its Quest 2 at a loss to build up a critical mass of users. This autumn it will release the Quest 3, a pass-through device which will be far less capable than Apple's but, at $499, a more realistic prospect for most consumers.

The second reason Apple wants to get its product out is because it already has its eye on what comes next. Tech types have long speculated that it will eventually be possible to have a pair of AR glasses as thin and unobtrusive as a pair of sun shades, at which point headsets will stop being clunky things for nerds and start becoming something that normal people might wear all day. Such devices might even replace the smartphone as the next big tech platform. “I don't think there's a doubt in anyone's mind that AR is the future,” says Jitesh Ubrani of IDC , another data company. Apple's presentation characterised the Vision Pro as “the start of an entirely new platform”.

Glasses half full

The strategy is not without risk. Apple has a reputation for releasing perfect, polished products. Releasing a $3,499 device with a two-hour battery life could amount to what Steve Jobs, Mr Cook's late predecessor, used to characterise as a “brand withdrawal”.

It is also not yet clear what people will do with their devices. So far VR headsets have been used mostly for gaming : nearly 90% of VR content spending last year was on games, estimates Omdia. Meta's Quest Pro has failed to excite professionals with its promise of in-person video conferencing and the like. Apple's Vision Pro presentation, though characteristically slick, had nothing resembling a “killer app”. There are some exciting features, such as the ability to take 3 D photos and videos, turning the device into a “nostalgia generator”, says Mr Ubrani. But most of Apple's suggested uses for the Vision Pro seem to involve treating it as a sort of giant virtual desktop, using floating windows of Zoom chats or Excel spreadsheets, or watching a film on a giant virtual screen. None of this is anywhere near as innovative as the technology itself.

Still, Apple enjoys big advantages over its rivals. It has a huge existing user base , with 2bn devices in circulation. The Vision Pro presentation showed how the headset synchronises with Apple's other gadgets: users can do FaceTime video calls with friends on their iPhones or project a MacBook laptop screen into the headset just by looking at it. Apps for the iPhone and iPad will be compatible with the Vision Pro, meaning there will be hundreds of thousands of apps available at launch—albeit ones not optimised for the device.

Apple's strategy is also straightforward: make the best headset and charge consumers a lot of money for it, and, presumably, also charge developers a slice of their app earnings, as happens in the App Store. Although the firm seems focused on the eventual goal of AR , that is quite different from the VR -centric metaverse that Mark Zuckerberg, Meta's boss, has talked so much about.

Apple also has a trusted brand among consumers. In a survey in 2021, three times as many people said they would buy a headset from Apple as from the second-placed company, Google. Meta came sixth. It has leverage with developers, too. It will have apps from Microsoft, as well as Zoom and Webex, and a partnership with Unity. Bob Iger, Disney's chief executive and a former friend of Jobs, made a surprise cameo in the presentation to praise Apple's “revolutionary platform” and show off how the headset might allow audiences to watch a “Star Wars” movie before being transported in virtual reality to the planet of Tatooine, or watch 3 D replays of a basketball match in VR on Disney's ESPN sports network. Having Mickey Mouse, or even the Disneyland castle, appear in the sitting room—“Bring[ing] Disney to our fans in ways that were previously impossible”, as Mr Iger put it—is the sort of thing that might excite people more than virtual conferencing.

Few people are likely to cough up for the Vision Pro, at least initially. But Mr Cook, who compared it to the launch of the Mac and the iPhone, said it was the “beginning of a journey”. It may yet be that the journey leads somewhere profitable. As Mr Ubrani puts it, “When Apple enters a market, it completely changes the trajectory of the market.” ■

; Thu, 01 Jun 2023 12:58:52 GMT /content/78aqof5scf70dkq845v23k1v23rsseln https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/01/chief-executives-cannot-shut-up-about-ai Go First’s insolvency tests India’s bankruptcy regime

G O FIRST , an Indian low-cost airline, collapsed in May under the weight of four years of losses, citations for safety lapses and operating confusion that, in January, resulted in a flight from Bangalore to Delhi carrying baggage but forgetting a third of its passengers. At least the carrier held valuable assets in the form of 45 or so aircraft stranded at Indian airports. And, as a high-priority case, it was supposedly subject to expedited bankruptcy hearings.

A prompt liquidation and redeployment of assets has obvious benefits for the aviation industry, its creditors and, possibly, for rivals keen to snap up its planes to add capacity in response to packed flights. Not so fast, the court hearing Go First's case now appears to be saying. Rather than allow easily identifiable assets like the company's aeroplanes to be reclaimed while more complicated financial ones are unwound, it has placed a blanket hold on all the airline's assets.

The Go First roadblocks are indicative of longstanding problems with bankruptcy in India. These were meant to be solved by a new insolvency code introduced in 2016. That code's provisions shifted power from indebted companies, protected by a morass of earlier rules, to their creditors. It allowed some interminable bankruptcy proceedings at last to come to an end, for example forcing the sale of Essar Steel, an industrial giant which had been in default to various creditors as far back as 2002. A smooth journey through the court system was meant to send a bigger message—that the risk of lending to Indian businesses could be mitigated by ensuring that collateral is readily transferable. This, the argument went, would help reduce borrowing costs for corporate India more broadly.

Despite a few successes such as Essar, however, the regime has not lived up to its promise. One persistent problem has been the low recovery rate for creditors' claims. In the past seven years lenders to a company that presented a successful resolution plan received a paltry 32% of their claims, on average. And only one in four bankrupt firms present such a plan; the remaining three-quarters of cases end in liquidation, for which creditors' average recovery rate is a dismal 7% of what they are owed.

The official figures may overstate the actual returns of what creditors are owed. They take no account of the time and effort involved in the process—the second problem with the code as applied in practice. Under the law, cases are to be resolved within 330 days. The latest quarterly update by the law's administrator, the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Board of India, indicated that cases leading to a liquidation took an average of 456 days to conclude. The average for cases in which the company survived through a resolution plan was a gobsmacking 614 days. The number of applications that are taking more than two years rose to 85 in the 12 months to March 2022, from 15 a year before. Bankruptcy lawyers grumble that submitting an application in the first place is becoming harder, and can itself now take a couple of years.

Fixing India's bankruptcy process may require revisions to the law. It could, for instance, do with a clearer distinction between tangible and less tangible assets of the sort that has historically allowed things like railway carriages to be repossessed quickly and leased out in jurisdictions such as America.

The bankruptcy system also needs more resources. As the number of cases keeps rising, so does the backlog (see chart). Unlike India's older courts, often ensconced in palatial buildings, the country's busiest bankruptcy forum in Mumbai occupies an upper floor of a dilapidated old building owned by MTNL , an ailing state-owned telecoms provider. In theory, its five courtrooms operate six hours a day. Lawyers say that in practice four hours is more common. Without enough judges to man all five benches, some courtrooms remain empty. As an exasperated banker involved in many insolvencies puts it, “No one is winning now.” ■

I F AUSTRALIA AND Canada were one economy, this “Ozanada” would be the world's fifth-largest, bigger than India and just behind Germany. Considering the two in tandem is not as nutty as it seems. Weather aside, they have a remarkable amount in common. Both are vast land masses populated by comparatively few people and dangerous wildlife. Both are (mostly) English-speaking realms of King Charles III. Both export their rich natural resources around the planet. And both are magnets for immigration.

Their worlds of business, too, are near-identical. Macquarie, an Australian financial group, is the world's largest infrastructure-investment manager. Brookfield, a Canadian peer, is the runner-up. Fittingly, Australia has produced a number of top surf-clothing labels, just as Canada has developed a niche in parkas and other winterwear. And, of course, both are home to commodities giants. But the main thread that connects Ozanada Inc is less fetching. As Rod Sims, former head of Australia's competition watchdog puts it, his country's firms have “forgotten how to compete”. So have their Canadian counterparts.

Many hands have been wrung in recent years over oligopolies in America. Yet next to Ozanada, the world's largest economy looks like a paragon of perfect competition. Coles and Woolworths, Australia's biggest supermarkets, sell 59% of its groceries, according to GlobalData, a research firm. Loblaws and Sobeys peddle 34% of Canada's—more than the combined share of the top four grocers in America. In both Australia and Canada the four biggest banks hold three-quarters of domestic deposits, compared with less than half in America. In both countries domestic aviation is a duopoly and telecoms a triopoly. The list goes on.

Part of the explanation for Ozanada's oligopolistic tendencies is benign. If companies need to be of a certain scale to be economically viable—to afford the necessary investments in computer systems, for example—then a small economy may be unable to support more than a few players in many industries. Ozanadian national champions, notably its grocers and lenders, are, however, meaningfully more profitable than their American counterparts. That points to other, less innocent causes.

Toothless antitrust regimes in both countries set a high bar for blocking mergers, permitting consolidation. A lack of openness to foreign investment doesn't help. Of the 38 members of the OECD , only three—Iceland, Mexico and New Zealand—are less open to foreign investment. Stringent screening, ownership caps and various other hurdles make setting up shop in Ozanada a hassle for foreigners. In 2013 Naguib Sawiris, an Egyptian telecoms tycoon, swore he would never again invest in Canada after his bid to acquire the fibre-optic network of Manitoba Telecom Services ( MTS ), a Canadian carrier, was rejected by the government with little explanation. Four years later MTS was purchased in its entirety by Bell Canada, a local rival.

All this may reflect a unique Ozanadian spin on the “resource curse” that has brought political instability and underdevelopment to commodity-rich countries in Africa and South America. Ozanada's natural bounty has weakened its incentive to build globally competitive industries in other areas. That may explain why, beyond commodities and outdoor apparel, the list of successful Ozanadian multinationals is so short. Canada's banks have dipped a toe in America, but remain small fry. Its life insurers have fared only a bit better south of the border, mostly thanks to big acquisitions. Vegemite, a divisive Australian spread, has yet to win over foreign sandwich-eaters.

Ozanada Inc's limitations are particularly acute at the cutting edge of technology. Products deemed “high-tech” by the World Bank, such as computers and drugs, represent more than 7% of the combined exports of OECD members, but only 4% for Canada and less than 2% for Australia. Patents granted per 10,000 people are a mere 5.9 in Canada and 6.7 in Australia, compared with 9.9 in America and 28.2 in South Korea.

This is not for want of well-nourished brains; Ozanada is home to world-class universities and boasts some of the highest rates of tertiary education in the OECD . Rather, the problem is an underfed innovation system. Spending on research and development comes to just 1.7% and 1.8% of GDP in Canada and Australia, respectively, against an OECD average of 2.7%. Total venture-capital investment in Ozanada was a mere $16bn in 2022, roughly half the level in Britain. Atlassian and Canva, two Australian technology successes, and Shopify, a Canadian one, have not prompted a lot of fresh prospecting for the next generation of tech winners.

Dormant animal spirits

To Ozanadians, this may all seem academic. After all, among citizens of countries with at least 20m inhabitants, only America's are richer. But they used to be better off than Americans: after soaring in the first decade of the 2000s thanks to rising commodity prices, their GDP per person briefly surpassed America's in the early 2010s in dollar terms. And a fate tethered to demand for commodities may prove particularly volatile in the decades to come.

Canada, with its reliance on oil and gas exports, could be dragged down by decarbonisation. Australia will be somewhat insulated by its vast deposits of copper and other minerals needed for the green transition. But it could suffer from its dependence on shipping commodities to China. In 2020 China began introducing restrictions on Australian coal, timber and other products, seemingly in retaliation for calls by Australia's then government for an inquiry into the origins of covid-19. Australia weathered those restrictions, which have since been loosened, surprisingly well. A long-term slowdown in China's economic growth, though, which many economists now expect, would weigh heavily on the country. Ozanada's economic model is not about to collapse. In time, though, its corporate weaknesses may come back to bite it. ■
